The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs informed the Cabinet as to the negotiations which had led up to the Allied reply to the German rejoinder onthe subject of German disarmament and the evacuation of Cologne. He himself had been anxious not to be committed in any way until he knew more about the- facts of German disarmament. Consequently, he had suggested the terms of a draft reply to Lord Crewe, for "his useat the Conference of Ambassadors. This had produced a counter draft, prepared by M. Cambon and Marshal Foch,which had not been acceptable. Eventually a reply tothe German rejoinder had been agreed to, which wascouched in moderate terms and showed the real desire of the Allies to evacuate the Cologne Zone as soon asthey were satisfied that the Treaty of Versailles hadbeen complied with.
